Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Project: Developing Faculty Expertise in Information Assurance through Case Studies and Hands-on Experiences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Three universities, North Carolina A & T State University, the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, and the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, are collaboratively developing faculty expertise in information assurance (IA) and computer security through two faculty development workshops. Covering two years, the workshops involve thirty-six faculty members from two-year, four-year, and minority colleges and universities. The workshops are helping participants to integrate IA labs and case studies into the curricula at the participants' home institutions. The workshops are designed to increase the faculty members' expertise and their home institution's capacity to produce a diverse workforce in the area of information assurance. Personalized instruction plans and follow-up assistance are provided to faculty participants. Besides building faculty expertise, the project is improving partnerships in information assurance education.

This project is improving overall information security and critical infrastructure protection in the U.S. by producing a larger and more diverse IA workforce with better IA skills. The curriculum materials disseminated through the workshops can be adopted across multiple disciplines such as computer science, software engineering, information technology and business, and are being made available to a broader audience through conferences, publication, and a dedicated website. The project is building a community of security education experts across multiple disciplines. Broad coverage of IA topics and the introduction of innovative teaching techniques are attracting faculty participants with diverse backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support from this grant, we conducted two faculty development workshops during the summers of 2012 and 2013 to disseminate effective pedagogical practices to faculty in computer science. The Information Assurance (IA) workshops demonstrated and taught faculty hands-on exercises and case studies for the enhancement of classroom teaching. The workshops provided training for 38 instructors and covered a broad topical range. The hands-on exercises and case studies disseminated through the workshops were developed to be integrated across computer science curriculum, and with the goal that these teaching methods be adopted by diverse disciplines such as computer science, software engineering, information technology and business. The overall project goals were to 1) build faculty capacity in information assurance education and training, 2) increase student interest and learning in information assurance, and 3) increase partnerships between institutions in information assurance education. The following report provides summative evaluation of the project outcomes beginning with finding highlights, followed by summative findings for each goal. The report concludes with a summative assessment of project outcomes.

 Highlights of Overall Findings

The first summer workshop was held in Chattanooga, TN in May 2012 with 19 participants, and the second workshop was conducted in Greensboro, NC in May 2013 with 19 participants.  Hands-on exercises and case studies for teaching IA were presented and practiced during the workshops.   Measurable outcomes included faculty participant surveys and focus groups of workshop satisfaction, perceived utility of IA materials, attitudes toward and interest in IA education, and adoption of IA materials covered during the workshops. Long-term follow up was also conducted with workshop participants, and a comparison survey of faculty who had applied to attend the workshops but did not participate was conducted to observe any differences in teaching methods between workshop attendees and nonparticipants. Additional project objectives were to enhance student learning and interest in information assurance topics. Measurable outcomes included pre/post surveys and tracking of course grades as submitted from faculty workshop participants. Highlights include the following points.

Faculty Indicators
• Faculty workshop participants reported high levels of satisfaction with the content and tools, and knowledge gains in both 2012 and 2013 workshops
• Faculty reported use of case study materials and tools presented at the workshops in subsequently taught courses, and ease of use
• Collaborations among faculty workshop participants were gained via online wiki and direct contact across participants
• 11  publications relating to IA were reported by workshop participants following their attendance

Student Learning Indicators
• Gains were found in student conceptual knowledge in pre/post surveys in courses implementing workshop hands-on activities and case studies
• Passing grades in IA comparison courses increased after deploying the workshop methods, while failing grades decreased
